fol.203r
May it please yo
r
good L. to be advertised
that
e 5 day of this moneth, when
e
Count
w
t
all his troupes was come before
Steenwicke,
there
came intelligence from all quarters,
at
e Enemie
was entred
e Betuwe fast by
Nieumeghen.
There came also many letters from
e
General states
e Provinces of
Guelders
and
Utrecht
,
e
Count
of
Culen
bourgh
,
e
Ammand of
Tiel
, and others, re-
quiring very earnestly,
at
e enterprise of Steen-
wicke, and all other purposes sett apart,
e campe
should come forward to
e assistance of those places,
w
ch
e Enemie might otherwise very mightily en-
dommage. Upon this intelligence, and
e instance
of
e contrey, it was presently resolved
at
ei would
not stay at
Steenwicke
: and so muche
e rather,
for
at
e Count and
e army were nothing yet enga-
ged, nether by summoning
e towne, nor by plan-
ting their artillerie, nor by quartering
e compa-
nies, nor by any other action,
at might make
their departure prejudiciall to their hono
r
. Howbeit
for
e better preservation of those places,
at were
taken about
Groninghen,
it was deemed expedient
that
Count William
w
t
his troupes of
Friseland
,
w
ch
were to
e nomber of 2000 should remaine still
in Frise: and
at Count Maurice w
t
e rest, ma-
king at
e lest, by all conjecture,
5000 foote
, and
5000
fo
1300
h
1300
horse, should marche towardes
Arnham
.
Upon w
ch
resolution all o
r
forces, aswell of horsmen
as footemen arrived yesterday heere: where we
hope to be renforced, from out of
e Garrisons of these
quarters, w
t
2000
men more. The furnishing
of those fortes,
at were taken about Groninghen,
amounting by tale to
32 in
all, did greatly di-
minishe
e strength of o
r
army. Nevertheles for
ought
at we can learne by prisoners, spies, and
other meanes,
e Enemie for footmen is weaker then
we are: but his horsemen, it is thought, are 2000 at
e lest. Moreover we doe finde, that the
fol.203v
Duke
himself in person, w
t
all his forces, two regi-
ments of footmen, and 4 cornets of horse excepted,
w
ch
are left beside Nieumeghen, for
e custody of
their bagage, are already in
e
Betuwe
. He hath
also made his approches, and planted
8 peeces
of batterie before
Cnossenbourgh
,
w
ch
is that fort,
at
we built
e last sommer on this side
e Wael, be-
fore
e towne of Nieumeghen. Albeit we have
sent abroade very many, to learne his designes
and
e state of his army, yet we finde their infor-
mations to differ so muche,
at we can build upon
nothing, but
at
ei are
in
some miserie for want of
victuals, wherein all doe accord. They are
served of their victuals from
Collen
,
Bosleduke
,
Grave
,
and from
e land
of
Cleve,
by
e way of
Emmericke
,
from whens they bring it all by land
to certaine places by Nieumeghen, and there trans-
port it by scutes to
e Enemies campe. They
have passed all their troupes, both horse and foote,
w
t
2 great pontons, of w
ch
ether is thought suffi-
cient, for 300 men at a passage.
This strange adventure of
e Duke, in comming
over
e river, doth wonderfully astonishe
e people
of this contrey: who are all of one opinion, that he
hath putte himself in so muche danger, as he can
not any way goe backe, w
t
out notable losse. To
e effecting wherof heere are two waies proposed,
The one by sending over o
r
forces to
Nieumeghen
side, thereby to cutte of his victuals, and to stoppe
his returne: the other by passing
e Rhine heere
at
Arnham
, and by marching in
e Betuwe, di-
rectly towardes him: w
t
suche good cautions for the
order of their marche, for
e making of trenches, and
for using other martial meanes, as they will ether
have in choise to fight if
ei list, or being forced
therunto, to doe it w
t
out
e hazard of
e body
of their army. But howsoever, we hope it is
a way, to relieve
at Fort in some sort,
at is
fol.204r
presently besieged, and before
e Enemie shall reco-
ver
e other side of
e river, to cutte of some part
of
e arriergarde of his army. Howbeit
e fort, though
w
t
in it be all thing requisit, and
800
men in Gar-
rison, yet we doubt it will be taken, or surrendred
in
e ende: as we also make account, when
e Duke
is departed, to recover it againe. Of
e forsaide 2
waies, because
e first is subject to very many diffi-
culties, and wold be longe in perfourming, conside-
ring
at
e troupes are to passe over
3 rivers
, they are
wholy as yet inclined to put
e later in execution,
for w
ch
their bridge for
e Rhine is already provi-
ded, and will be happely placed some time to day,
so as all
e souldiers may passe over towardes night.
And this is nowe in summe
e state of o
r
affaires,
w
ch
I doe signifie continually, as messengers and matter
are presented where I am.
And so I take at this
present my humble leave of yo
r
L.
From Arnham. July 11 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley

at

those w
t

and have ether slaine or very
dangerously
